euclid.euclid2

euclid.euclid2.angle(A, B, C)

returns the angle \(\angle ABC\). The equation used to compute the angle is,

\[\angle ABC = \mathrm{atan2}\left( {C_y - B_y},\ {C_x - B_x} \right) - \mathrm{atan2}\left( {A_y - B_y},\ {A_x - B_x} \right) \pmod{360^{\circ}}\]

where \(A = \left( A_x,\ A_y \right)\), \(B = \left( B_x,\ B_y \right)\) and \(C = \left( C_x,\ C_y \right)\)

Parameters

  • A (np.ndarray, tuple or list) – The point \(A\)

  • B (np.ndarray, tuple or list) – The point \(B\)

  • C (np.ndarray, tuple or list) – The point \(C\)

Returns

The angle \(\angle ABC\)

Return type

float

Examples

>>> from euclid import *
>>> A = [1, 2]
>>> B = [0, -2]
>>> C = [-2, 2]
>>> theta = angle(A, B, C)
>>> print(theta)
40.601294645004
euclid.euclid2.convex_hull(*points)

Returns the convex hull of points.

Parameters

*points (np.ndarray, list or tuple) – The points whose convex hull you want to find.

Returns

The list of all of points on the convex hull.

Return type

list

Examples

>>> from euclid import *
>>> import numpy as np
>>> rng = np.random.default_rng()
>>> points = [col_vector(point) for point in rng.random((100, 2))*10]
>>> print(points)
[array([[2.00756707],
       [7.91470412]]), array([[1.01901632],
       [9.43917478]]), array([[8.63472305],
       ...,
       [9.55533233]]), array([[7.87207801],
       [5.4060051 ]]), array([[6.02948716],
       [5.29350243]])]
>>> hull = convex_hull(*points)
>>> print(hull)
[array([[5.69873368],
       [0.07473919]]), array([[9.46265076],
       [0.08784139]]), array([[9.89536912],
       ...,
       [0.76708439]]), array([[3.07070786],
       [0.08520319]])]
